results.title: Princess of the Blood Robes from The Last Emperor
results.brief_description:
A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.

results.title: Princess of the Blood robes costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description: This costume from The Last Emperor enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.description:
From seller: A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
description_for_label: Colour had arrived in cinema when The Last Emperor (1987) was released but its use in costume and cinematography was Oscar-winning. The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen and colour is fundamental to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates moments in jail later in life. This costume by James Acheson enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, further reinforced by 9,500 extras that appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.credit_line_for_label:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric

results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

results.title: Wind
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Graeme Isaac, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABS, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
1857, The Australian Alps. Jess, a young black tracker and his elderly sergeant discover the body of a gold miner. They track the killer, an old Aboriginal man, to a cabin on a clear plateau. After losing their horse and with the sergeant in bad health they are forced to shelter in a cabin. As Jess falls asleep he is visited in his dreams by the old Aboriginal man. When Jess is faced with executing the old man he is forced to decide his fate, to choose his friend the sergeant, or to follow his ancestral soul. Cast includes Ralph Cotterill, Bradley Byqar and Steve Dodd.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivan Sen, Graeme Isaac, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABS, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission

results.title: Saturday night: Sunday morning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Based on the Archie Weller short story, this film takes us on a journey into the discontented life of Melanie as she grapples with adolescence, rural isolation and life with her dysfunctional father. Her difficulties escalate when she is taken hostage by three young men for whom life has very little meaning and actions have no consequences. Essentially a rites of passage drama, both Melanie and her captors struggle to come to terms with assumptions of difference, indigenous and non-indigenous race relations, institutionalised injustice, and loss. Cast includes Alyssa McClelland, Peter Browne and Luke Caroll.

results.title: Harry's War
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Frankland, John Foss, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Victoria, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, AFI [au] and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Manyu-Wana
results.brief_description: Set among the red dirt, campfires, rock music and dreaming stories of an Aboriginal community in Central Australia, these programs were produced to help local children learn literacy and maths in their own language, Warlpiri. Scenes around the community, animation, puppet and magic characters are used to introduce letters, syllables, numbers and other maths concepts, and to illustrate story books. Traditional skills and activities are featured in segments on hunting and gathering bush foods, fire-making, traditional ceremonies and painting, and dreamtime stories about the landscape. An Aboriginal “Sesame Street”, this series of programs is suitable for use as a teaching/study resource for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.
